messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> ezra_epstein wrote:
>
> > But the real reason is de-coupling. With annotations you don't need
> > to inherit from a framework (jUnit) class. You simply annotate the
> > class and it becomes a TestCase. This means you don't need to break
> > out your tests into separate classes (though one is still free to do
> > so).
>
> I'm biased, being a JUnit user, but I don't like the idea of tests
> living in with the class under test. My objection is that it implicitly
> encourages a testing style with which I disagree: that there is a 1:1
> correspondence between fixtures and classes under test.
>
> I do admit that in those cases where the 1:1 correspondence holds, it
> might be better to put tests and production code together, but I
usually
> have a large number of small test methods, and I feel like that would
> pollute my production code.
>
> ...or did you mean something else entirely? :)
> --

I think I meant the more general case of just not being bound to
inherit from a jUnit framework class. That's the main point. Since
Java is single inheritance there are times when you want to have your
test live in some framework (say testing in J2EE) and having to
inherit from the jUnit class becomes an obstacle to testing in some of
those cases. (There are other obstacles too, of course.) So I meant
the benefits of decoupling. The framework can run tests and still be
automatic without imposing any requirements on the hierarchy of the
test classes.
